Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me
Your fellow tribune.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
You show too much of that
For which the people stir: if you will pass
To where you are bound, you must inquire your way,
Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit,
Or never be so noble as a consul,
Nor yoke with him for tribune.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Let's be calm.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
The people are abused; set on. This paltering
Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus
Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely
I' the plain way of his merit.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Tell me of corn!
This was my speech, and I will speak't again—

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Not now, not now.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: Not in this heat, sir, now.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Now, as I live, I will. My nobler friends,
I crave their pardons:
For the mutable, rank-scented many, let them
Regard me as I do not flatter, and
Therein behold themselves: I say again,
In soothing them, we nourish 'gainst our senate
The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition,
Which we ourselves have plough'd for, sow'd,
and scatter'd,
By mingling them with us, the honour'd number,
Who lack not virtue, no, nor power, but that
Which they have given to beggars.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Well, no more.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: No more words, we beseech you.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
How! no more!
As for my country I have shed my blood,
Not fearing outward force, so shall my lungs
Coin words till their decay against those measles,
Which we disdain should tatter us, yet sought
The very way to catch them.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
You speak o' the people,
As if you were a god to punish, not
A man of their infirmity.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
'Twere well
We let the people know't.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: What, what? his choler?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Choler!
Were I as patient as the midnight sleep,
By Jove, 'twould be my mind!

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
It is a mind
That shall remain a poison where it is,
Not poison any further.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Shall remain!
Hear you this Triton of the minnows? mark you
His absolute 'shall'?

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: 'Twas from the canon.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
'Shall'!
O good but most unwise patricians! why,
You grave but reckless senators, have you thus
Given Hydra here to choose an officer,
That with his peremptory 'shall,' being but
The horn and noise o' the monster's, wants not spirit
To say he'll turn your current in a ditch,
And make your channel his? If he have power
Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake
Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd,
Be not as common fools; if you are not,
Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians,
If they be senators: and they are no less,
When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste
Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate,
And such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,'
His popular 'shall' against a graver bench
Than ever frown in Greece. By Jove himself!
It makes the consuls base: and my soul aches
To know, when two authorities are up,
Neither supreme, how soon confusion
May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take
The one by the other.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: Well, on to the market-place.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Whoever gave that counsel, to give forth
The corn o' the storehouse gratis, as 'twas used
Sometime in Greece,—

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Well, well, no more of that.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Though there the people had more absolute power,
I say, they nourish'd disobedience, fed
The ruin of the state.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Why, shall the people give
One that speaks thus their voice?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
I'll give my reasons,
More worthier than their voices. They know the corn
Was not our recompense, resting well assured
That ne'er did service for't: being press'd to the war,
Even when the navel of the state was touch'd,
They would not thread the gates. This kind of service
Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i' the war
Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they show'd
Most valour, spoke not for them: the accusation
Which they have often made against the senate,
All cause unborn, could never be the motive
Of our so frank donation. Well, what then?
How shall this bisson multitude digest
The senate's courtesy? Let deeds express
What's like to be their words: 'we did request it;
We are the greater poll, and in true fear
They gave us our demands.' Thus we debase
The nature of our seats and make the rabble
Call our cares fears; which will in time
Break ope the locks o' the senate and bring in
The crows to peck the eagles.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Come, enough.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Enough, with over-measure.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
No, take more:
What may be sworn by, both divine and human,
Seal what I end withal! This double worship,
Where one part does disdain with cause, the other
Insult without all reason, where gentry, title, wisdom,
Cannot conclude but by the yea and no
Of general ignorance,—it must omit
Real necessities, and give way the while
To unstable slightness: purpose so barr'd,
it follows,
Nothing is done to purpose. Therefore, beseech you,—
You that will be less fearful than discreet,
That love the fundamental part of state
More than you doubt the change on't, that prefer
A noble life before a long, and wish
To jump a body with a dangerous physic
That's sure of death without it, at once pluck out
The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick
The sweet which is their poison: your dishonour
Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state
Of that integrity which should become't,
Not having the power to do the good it would,
For the in which doth control't.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Has said enough.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Has spoken like a traitor, and shall answer
As traitors do.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee!
What should the people do with these bald tribunes?
On whom depending, their obedience fails
To the greater bench: in a rebellion,
When what's not meet, but what must be, was law,
Then were they chosen: in a better hour,
Let what is meet be said it must be meet,
And throw their power i' the dust.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Manifest treason!

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: This a consul? no.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: The aediles, ho!
Let him be apprehended.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Go, call the people:

in whose name myself
Attach thee as a traitorous innovator,
A foe to the public weal: obey, I charge thee,
And follow to thine answer.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Hence, old goat!

sp.speaker: Senators
sp.p:
, &C
We'll surety him.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: Aged sir, hands off.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Hence, rotten thing! or I shall shake thy bones
Out of thy garments.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Help, ye citizens!

p.stage: Enter a rabble of Citizens (Plebeians), with the AEdiles

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: On both sides more respect.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Here's he that would take from you all your power.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Seize him, AEdiles!

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: Down with him! down with him!

sp.speaker: Senators, &C.
sp.p: Weapons, weapons, weapons!

p.stage: They all bustle about CORIOLANUS, crying

sp.p:
'Tribunes!' 'Patricians!' 'Citizens!' 'What, ho!'
'Sicinius!' 'Brutus!' 'Coriolanus!' 'Citizens!'
'Peace, peace, peace!' 'Stay, hold, peace!'

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
What is about to be? I am out of breath;
Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You, tribunes
To the people! Coriolanus, patience!
Speak, good Sicinius.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Hear me, people; peace!

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: Let's hear our tribune: peace Speak, speak, speak.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
You are at point to lose your liberties:
Marcius would have all from you; Marcius,
Whom late you have named for consul.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Fie, fie, fie!
This is the way to kindle, not to quench.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: What is the city but the people?

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p:
True,
The people are the city.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
By the consent of all, we were establish'd
The people's magistrates.

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: You so remain.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: And so are like to do.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
That is the way to lay the city flat;
To bring the roof to the foundation,
And bury all, which yet distinctly ranges,
In heaps and piles of ruin.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: This deserves death.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Or let us stand to our authority,
Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce,
Upon the part o' the people, in whose power
We were elected theirs, Marcius is worthy
Of present death.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
BRUTUS
sp.p: AEdiles, seize him!

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: Yield, Marcius, yield!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Hear me one word;
Beseech you, tribunes, hear me but a word.

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p: Peace, peace!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Be that you seem, truly your
country's friend,
And temperately proceed to what you would
Thus violently redress.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Sir, those cold ways,
That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous
Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him,
And bear him to the rock.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: No, I'll die here.

There's some among you have beheld me fighting:
Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Lay hands upon him.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
Help Marcius, help,
You that be noble; help him, young and old!

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: Down with him, down with him!

p.stage: In this mutiny, the Tribunes, the AEdiles, and the People, are beat in

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Go, get you to your house; be gone, away!
All will be naught else.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.p: Get you gone.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
Stand fast;
We have as many friends as enemies.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Sham it be put to that?

sp.speaker: First Senator
MENENIUS
sp.p:
For 'tis a sore upon us,
You cannot tent yourself: be gone, beseech you.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: Come, sir, along with us.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
I would they were barbarians—as they are,
Though in Rome litter'd—not Romans—as they are not,
Though calved i' the porch o' the Capitol—

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
On fair ground
I could beat forty of them.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
I could myself
Take up a brace o' the best of them; yea, the
two tribunes:
But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic;
And manhood is call'd foolery, when it stands
Against a falling fabric. Will you hence,
Before the tag return? whose rage doth rend
Like interrupted waters and o'erbear
What they are used to bear.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Pray you, be gone:
I'll try whether my old wit be in request
With those that have but little: this must be patch'd
With cloth of any colour.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: Nay, come away.

sp.speaker: A Patrician
sp.p: This man has marr'd his fortune.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
His nature is too noble for the world:
He would not flatter Neptune for his trident,
Or Jove for's power to thunder. His heart's his mouth:
What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent;
And, being angry, does forget that ever
He heard the name of death.
Here's goodly work!

sp.speaker: Second Patrician
sp.p: I would they were abed!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
I would they were in Tiber! What the vengeance!
Could he not speak 'em fair?

p.stage: Re-enter BRUTUS and SICINIUS, with the rabble

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Where is this viper
That would depopulate the city and
Be every man himself?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: You worthy tribunes,—

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock
With rigorous hands: he hath resisted law,
And therefore law shall scorn him further trial
Than the severity of the public power
Which he so sets at nought.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p:
He shall well know
The noble tribunes are the people's mouths,
And we their hands.

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: He shall, sure on't.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Sir, sir,—

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Peace!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt
With modest warrant.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Sir, how comes't that you
Have holp to make this rescue?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Hear me speak:
As I do know the consul's worthiness,
So can I name his faults,—

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Consul! what consul?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: The consul Coriolanus.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: He consul!

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: No, no, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people,
I may be heard, I would crave a word or two;
The which shall turn you to no further harm
Than so much loss of time.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Speak briefly then;
For we are peremptory to dispatch
This viperous traitor: to eject him hence
Were but one danger, and to keep him here
Our certain death: therefore it is decreed
He dies to-night.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Now the good gods forbid
That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude
Towards her deserved children is enroll'd
In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam
Should now eat up her own!

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: He's a disease that must be cut away.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
O, he's a limb that has but a disease;
Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy.
What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?
Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost—
Which, I dare vouch, is more than that he hath,
By many an ounce—he dropp'd it for his country;
And what is left, to lose it by his country,
Were to us all, that do't and suffer it,
A brand to the end o' the world.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: This is clean kam.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Merely awry: when he did love his country,
It honour'd him.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
The service of the foot
Being once gangrened, is not then respected
For what before it was.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
We'll hear no more.
Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence:
Lest his infection, being of catching nature,
Spread further.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
One word more, one word.
This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find
The harm of unscann'd swiftness, will too late
Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process;
Lest parties, as he is beloved, break out,
And sack great Rome with Romans.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: If it were so,—

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
What do ye talk?
Have we not had a taste of his obedience?
Our aediles smote? ourselves resisted? Come.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Consider this: he has been bred i' the wars
Since he could draw a sword, and is ill school'd
In bolted language; meal and bran together
He throws without distinction. Give me leave,
I'll go to him, and undertake to bring him
Where he shall answer, by a lawful form,
In peace, to his utmost peril.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p:
Noble tribunes,
It is the humane way: the other course
Will prove too bloody, and the end of it
Unknown to the beginning.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Noble Menenius,
Be you then as the people's officer.
Masters, lay down your weapons.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Go not home.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there:
Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'll proceed
In our first way.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: I'll bring him to you.

Let me desire your company: he must come,
Or what is worst will follow.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: Pray you, let's to him.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Let them puff all about mine ears, present me
Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels,
Or pile ten hills on the Tarpeian rock,
That the precipitation might down stretch
Below the beam of sight, yet will I still
Be thus to them.

sp.speaker: A Patrician
sp.p: You do the nobler.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
I muse my mother
Does not approve me further, who was wont
To call them woollen vassals, things created
To buy and sell with groats, to show bare heads
In congregations, to yawn, be still and wonder,
When one but of my ordinance stood up
To speak of peace or war.

I talk of you:
Why did you wish me milder? would you have me
False to my nature? Rather say I play
The man I am.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
O, sir, sir, sir,
I would have had you put your power well on,
Before you had worn it out.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Let go.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
You might have been enough the man you are,
With striving less to be so; lesser had been
The thwartings of your dispositions, if
You had not show'd them how ye were disposed
Ere they lack'd power to cross you.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Let them hang.

sp.speaker: A Patrician
sp.p: Ay, and burn too.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
First Senator
VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Pray, be counsell'd:
I have a heart as little apt as yours,
But yet a brain that leads my use of anger
To better vantage.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Well said, noble woman?
Before he should thus stoop to the herd, but that
The violent fit o' the time craves it as physic
For the whole state, I would put mine armour on,
Which I can scarcely bear.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: What must I do?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Return to the tribunes.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Well, what then? what then?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Repent what you have spoke.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
For them! I cannot do it to the gods;
Must I then do't to them?

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
You are too absolute;
Though therein you can never be too noble,
But when extremities speak. I have heard you say,
Honour and policy, like unsever'd friends,
I' the war do grow together: grant that, and tell me,
In peace what each of them by the other lose,
That they combine not there.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Tush, tush!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: A good demand.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
If it be honour in your wars to seem
The same you are not, which, for your best ends,
You adopt your policy, how is it less or worse,
That it shall hold companionship in peace
With honour, as in war, since that to both
It stands in like request?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Why force you this?

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Because that now it lies you on to speak
To the people; not by your own instruction,
Nor by the matter which your heart prompts you,
But with such words that are but rooted in
Your tongue, though but bastards and syllables
Of no allowance to your bosom's truth.
Now, this no more dishonours you at all
Than to take in a town with gentle words,
Which else would put you to your fortune and
The hazard of much blood.
I would dissemble with my nature where
My fortunes and my friends at stake required
I should do so in honour: I am in this,
Your wife, your son, these senators, the nobles;
And you will rather show our general louts
How you can frown than spend a fawn upon 'em,
For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard
Of what that want might ruin.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Noble lady!
Come, go with us; speak fair: you may salve so,
Not what is dangerous present, but the loss
Of what is past.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
I prithee now, my son,
Go to them, with this bonnet in thy hand;
And thus far having stretch'd it—here be with them—
Thy knee bussing the stones—for in such business
Action is eloquence, and the eyes of the ignorant
More learned than the ears—waving thy head,
Which often, thus, correcting thy stout heart,
Now humble as the ripest mulberry
That will not hold the handling: or say to them,
Thou art their soldier, and being bred in broils
Hast not the soft way which, thou dost confess,
Were fit for thee to use as they to claim,
In asking their good loves, but thou wilt frame
Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far
As thou hast power and person.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
This but done,
Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours;
For they have pardons, being ask'd, as free
As words to little purpose.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Prithee now,
Go, and be ruled: although I know thou hadst rather
Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf
Than flatter him in a bower. Here is Cominius.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
I have been i' the market-place; and, sir,'tis fit
You make strong party, or defend yourself
By calmness or by absence: all's in anger.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Only fair speech.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
I think 'twill serve, if he
Can thereto frame his spirit.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
He must, and will
Prithee now, say you will, and go about it.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Must I go show them my unbarbed sconce?
Must I with base tongue give my noble heart
A lie that it must bear? Well, I will do't:
Yet, were there but this single plot to lose,
This mould of Marcius, they to dust should grind it
And throw't against the wind. To the market-place!
You have put me now to such a part which never
I shall discharge to the life.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: Come, come, we'll prompt you.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
I prithee now, sweet son, as thou hast said
My praises made thee first a soldier, so,
To have my praise for this, perform a part
Thou hast not done before.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Well, I must do't:
Away, my disposition, and possess me
Some harlot's spirit! my throat of war be turn'd,
Which quired with my drum, into a pipe
Small as an eunuch, or the virgin voice
That babies lulls asleep! the smiles of knaves
Tent in my cheeks, and schoolboys' tears take up
The glasses of my sight! a beggar's tongue
Make motion through my lips, and my arm'd knees,
Who bow'd but in my stirrup, bend like his
That hath received an alms! I will not do't,
Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth
And by my body's action teach my mind
A most inherent baseness.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
At thy choice, then:
To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour
Than thou of them. Come all to ruin; let
Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear
Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at death
With as big heart as thou. Do as thou list
Thy valiantness was mine, thou suck'dst it from me,
But owe thy pride thyself.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Pray, be content:
Mother, I am going to the market-place;
Chide me no more. I'll mountebank their loves,
Cog their hearts from them, and come home beloved
Of all the trades in Rome. Look, I am going:
Commend me to my wife. I'll return consul;
Or never trust to what my tongue can do
I' the way of flattery further.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p: Do your will.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
Away! the tribunes do attend you: arm yourself
To answer mildly; for they are prepared
With accusations, as I hear, more strong
Than are upon you yet.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
The word is 'mildly.' Pray you, let us go:
Let them accuse me by invention, I
Will answer in mine honour.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Ay, but mildly.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Well, mildly be it then. Mildly!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
In this point charge him home, that he affects
Tyrannical power: if he evade us there,
Enforce him with his envy to the people,
And that the spoil got on the Antiates
Was ne'er distributed.
What, will he come?

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p: He's coming.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: How accompanied?

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p:
With old Menenius, and those senators
That always favour'd him.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Have you a catalogue
Of all the voices that we have procured
Set down by the poll?

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p: I have; 'tis ready.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Have you collected them by tribes?

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Assemble presently the people hither;
And when they bear me say 'It shall be so
I' the right and strength o' the commons,' be it either
For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them
If I say fine, cry 'Fine;' if death, cry 'Death.'
Insisting on the old prerogative
And power i' the truth o' the cause.

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p: I shall inform them.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
And when such time they have begun to cry,
Let them not cease, but with a din confused
Enforce the present execution
Of what we chance to sentence.

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Make them be strong and ready for this hint,
When we shall hap to give 't them.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Go about it.

Put him to choler straight: he hath been used
Ever to conquer, and to have his worth
Of contradiction: being once chafed, he cannot
Be rein'd again to temperance; then he speaks
What's in his heart; and that is there which looks
With us to break his neck.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Well, here he comes.

p.stage: Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS, and COMINIUS, with Senators and Patricians

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Calmly, I do beseech you.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Ay, as an ostler, that for the poorest piece
Will bear the knave by the volume. The honour'd gods
Keep Rome in safety, and the chairs of justice
Supplied with worthy men! plant love among 's!
Throng our large temples with the shows of peace,
And not our streets with war!

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: Amen, amen.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: A noble wish.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Draw near, ye people.

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p: List to your tribunes. Audience: peace, I say!

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: First, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Both Tribunes
sp.p: Well, say. Peace, ho!

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Shall I be charged no further than this present?
Must all determine here?

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
I do demand,
If you submit you to the people's voices,
Allow their officers and are content
To suffer lawful censure for such faults
As shall be proved upon you?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: I am content.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Lo, citizens, he says he is content:
The warlike service he has done, consider; think
Upon the wounds his body bears, which show
Like graves i' the holy churchyard.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Scratches with briers,
Scars to move laughter only.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Consider further,
That when he speaks not like a citizen,
You find him like a soldier: do not take
His rougher accents for malicious sounds,
But, as I say, such as become a soldier,
Rather than envy you.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: Well, well, no more.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
What is the matter
That being pass'd for consul with full voice,
I am so dishonour'd that the very hour
You take it off again?

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Answer to us.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Say, then: 'tis true, I ought so.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
We charge you, that you have contrived to take
From Rome all season'd office and to wind
Yourself into a power tyrannical;
For which you are a traitor to the people.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: How! traitor!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Nay, temperately; your promise.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
The fires i' the lowest hell fold-in the people!
Call me their traitor! Thou injurious tribune!
Within thine eyes sat twenty thousand deaths,
In thy hand clutch'd as many millions, in
Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say
'Thou liest' unto thee with a voice as free
As I do pray the gods.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Mark you this, people?

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: To the rock, to the rock with him!

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Peace!
We need not put new matter to his charge:
What you have seen him do and heard him speak,
Beating your officers, cursing yourselves,
Opposing laws with strokes and here defying
Those whose great power must try him; even this,
So criminal and in such capital kind,
Deserves the extremest death.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
But since he hath
Served well for Rome,—

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: What do you prate of service?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: I talk of that, that know it.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Is this the promise that you made your mother?

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: Know, I pray you,—

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
I know no further:
Let them pronounce the steep Tarpeian death,
Vagabond exile, raying, pent to linger
But with a grain a day, I would not buy
Their mercy at the price of one fair word;
Nor cheque my courage for what they can give,
To have't with saying 'Good morrow.'

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
For that he has,
As much as in him lies, from time to time
Envied against the people, seeking means
To pluck away their power, as now at last
Given hostile strokes, and that not in the presence
Of dreaded justice, but on the ministers
That do distribute it; in the name o' the people
And in the power of us the tribunes, we,
Even from this instant, banish him our city,
In peril of precipitation
From off the rock Tarpeian never more
To enter our Rome gates: i' the people's name,
I say it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p:
It shall be so, it shall be so; let him away:
He's banish'd, and it shall be so.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: Hear me, my masters, and my common friends,—

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: He's sentenced; no more hearing.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
Let me speak:
I have been consul, and can show for Rome
Her enemies' marks upon me. I do love
My country's good with a respect more tender,
More holy and profound, than mine own life,
My dear wife's estimate, her womb's increase,
And treasure of my loins; then if I would
Speak that,—

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: We know your drift: speak what?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
There's no more to be said, but he is banish'd,
As enemy to the people and his country:
It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: It shall be so, it shall be so.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
You common cry of curs! whose breath I hate
As reek o' the rotten fens, whose loves I prize
As the dead carcasses of unburied men
That do corrupt my air, I banish you;
And here remain with your uncertainty!
Let every feeble rumour shake your hearts!
Your enemies, with nodding of their plumes,
Fan you into despair! Have the power still
To banish your defenders; till at length
Your ignorance, which finds not till it feels,
Making not reservation of yourselves,
Still your own foes, deliver you as most
Abated captives to some nation
That won you without blows! Despising,
For you, the city, thus I turn my back:
There is a world elsewhere.

p.stage: Exeunt CORIOLANUS, COMINIUS, MENENIUS, Senators, and Patricians

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p: The people's enemy is gone, is gone!

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: Our enemy is banish'd! he is gone! Hoo! hoo!

p.stage: Shouting, and throwing up their caps

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Go, see him out at gates, and follow him,
As he hath followed you, with all despite;
Give him deserved vexation. Let a guard
Attend us through the city.

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p:
Come, come; let's see him out at gates; come.
The gods preserve our noble tribunes! Come.

p.stage: Rome. Before a gate of the city.
Enter CORIOLANUS, VOLUMNIA, VIRGILIA, MENENIUS, COMINIUS, with the young Nobility of Rome

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Come, leave your tears: a brief farewell: the beast
With many heads butts me away. Nay, mother,
Where is your ancient courage? you were used
To say extremity was the trier of spirits;
That common chances common men could bear;
That when the sea was calm all boats alike
Show'd mastership in floating; fortune's blows,
When most struck home, being gentle wounded, craves
A noble cunning: you were used to load me
With precepts that would make invincible
The heart that conn'd them.

sp.speaker: VIRGILIA
sp.p: O heavens! O heavens!

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Nay! prithee, woman,—

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Now the red pestilence strike all trades in Rome,
And occupations perish!

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
What, what, what!
I shall be loved when I am lack'd. Nay, mother.
Resume that spirit, when you were wont to say,
If you had been the wife of Hercules,
Six of his labours you'ld have done, and saved
Your husband so much sweat. Cominius,
Droop not; adieu. Farewell, my wife, my mother:
I'll do well yet. Thou old and true Menenius,
Thy tears are salter than a younger man's,
And venomous to thine eyes. My sometime general,
I have seen thee stem, and thou hast oft beheld
Heart-hardening spectacles; tell these sad women
'Tis fond to wail inevitable strokes,
As 'tis to laugh at 'em. My mother, you wot well
My hazards still have been your solace: and
Believe't not lightly—though I go alone,
Like to a lonely dragon, that his fen
Makes fear'd and talk'd of more than seen—your son
Will or exceed the common or be caught
With cautelous baits and practise.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
My first son.
Whither wilt thou go? Take good Cominius
With thee awhile: determine on some course,
More than a wild exposture to each chance
That starts i' the way before thee.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: O the gods!

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
I'll follow thee a month, devise with thee
Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us
And we of thee: so if the time thrust forth
A cause for thy repeal, we shall not send
O'er the vast world to seek a single man,
And lose advantage, which doth ever cool
I' the absence of the needer.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Fare ye well:
Thou hast years upon thee; and thou art too full
Of the wars' surfeits, to go rove with one
That's yet unbruised: bring me but out at gate.
Come, my sweet wife, my dearest mother, and
My friends of noble touch, when I am forth,
Bid me farewell, and smile. I pray you, come.
While I remain above the ground, you shall
Hear from me still, and never of me aught
But what is like me formerly.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
That's worthily
As any ear can hear. Come, let's not weep.
If I could shake off but one seven years
From these old arms and legs, by the good gods,
I'ld with thee every foot.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Give me thy hand: Come.

p.stage: The same. A street near the gate.
Enter SICINIUS, BRUTUS, and an AEdile

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Bid them all home; he's gone, and we'll no further.
The nobility are vex'd, whom we see have sided
In his behalf.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Now we have shown our power,
Let us seem humbler after it is done
Than when it was a-doing.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Bid them home:
Say their great enemy is gone, and they
Stand in their ancient strength.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Dismiss them home.
Here comes his mother.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Let's not meet her.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: They say she's mad.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: They have ta'en note of us: keep on your way.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
O, ye're well met: the hoarded plague o' the gods
Requite your love!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Peace, peace; be not so loud.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
If that I could for weeping, you should hear,—
Nay, and you shall hear some.
Will you be gone?

sp.speaker: VIRGILIA
sp.p:
You shall stay too: I would I had the power
To say so to my husband.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Are you mankind?

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Ay, fool; is that a shame? Note but this fool.
Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship
To banish him that struck more blows for Rome
Than thou hast spoken words?

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: O blessed heavens!

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
More noble blows than ever thou wise words;
And for Rome's good. I'll tell thee what; yet go:
Nay, but thou shalt stay too: I would my son
Were in Arabia, and thy tribe before him,
His good sword in his hand.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: VIRGILIA
sp.p:
What then!
He'ld make an end of thy posterity.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Bastards and all.
Good man, the wounds that he does bear for Rome!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Come, come, peace.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
I would he had continued to his country
As he began, and not unknit himself
The noble knot he made.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: I would he had.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
'I would he had'! 'Twas you incensed the rabble:
Cats, that can judge as fitly of his worth
As I can of those mysteries which heaven
Will not have earth to know.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Pray, let us go.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Now, pray, sir, get you gone:
You have done a brave deed. Ere you go, hear this:—
As far as doth the Capitol exceed
The meanest house in Rome, so far my son—
This lady's husband here, this, do you see—
Whom you have banish'd, does exceed you all.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Well, well, we'll leave you.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Why stay we to be baited
With one that wants her wits?

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p: Take my prayers with you.

I would the gods had nothing else to do
But to confirm my curses! Could I meet 'em
But once a-day, it would unclog my heart
Of what lies heavy to't.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
You have told them home;
And, by my troth, you have cause. You'll sup with me?

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Anger's my meat; I sup upon myself,
And so shall starve with feeding. Come, let's go:
Leave this faint puling and lament as I do,
In anger, Juno-like. Come, come, come.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Fie, fie, fie!

p.stage: A highway between Rome and Antium.
Enter a Roman and a Volsce, meeting

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p:
I know you well, sir, and you know
me: your name, I think, is Adrian.

sp.speaker: Volsce
sp.p: It is so, sir: truly, I have forgot you.

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p:
I am a Roman; and my services are,
as you are, against 'em: know you me yet?

sp.speaker: Volsce
sp.p: Nicanor? no.

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p: The same, sir.

sp.speaker: Volsce
sp.p:
You had more beard when I last saw you; but your
favour is well approved by your tongue. What's the
news in Rome? I have a note from the Volscian state,
to find you out there: you have well saved me a
day's journey.

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p:
There hath been in Rome strange insurrections; the
people against the senators, patricians, and nobles.

sp.speaker: Volsce
sp.p:
Hath been! is it ended, then? Our state thinks not
so: they are in a most warlike preparation, and
hope to come upon them in the heat of their division.

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p:
The main blaze of it is past, but a small thing
would make it flame again: for the nobles receive
so to heart the banishment of that worthy
Coriolanus, that they are in a ripe aptness to take
all power from the people and to pluck from them
their tribunes for ever. This lies glowing, I can
tell you, and is almost mature for the violent
breaking out.

sp.speaker: Volsce
sp.p: Coriolanus banished!

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p: Banished, sir.

sp.speaker: Volsce
sp.p: You will be welcome with this intelligence, Nicanor.

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p:
The day serves well for them now. I have heard it
said, the fittest time to corrupt a man's wife is
when she's fallen out with her husband. Your noble
Tullus Aufidius will appear well in these wars, his
great opposer, Coriolanus, being now in no request
of his country.

sp.speaker: Volsce
sp.p:
He cannot choose. I am most fortunate, thus
accidentally to encounter you: you have ended my
business, and I will merrily accompany you home.

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p:
I shall, between this and supper, tell you most
strange things from Rome; all tending to the good of
their adversaries. Have you an army ready, say you?

sp.speaker: Volsce
sp.p:
A most royal one; the centurions and their charges,
distinctly billeted, already in the entertainment,
and to be on foot at an hour's warning.

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p:
I am joyful to hear of their readiness, and am the
man, I think, that shall set them in present action.
So, sir, heartily well met, and most glad of your company.

sp.speaker: Volsce
sp.p:
You take my part from me, sir; I have the most cause
to be glad of yours.

sp.speaker: Roman
sp.p: Well, let us go together.

p.stage: Enter CORIOLANUS in mean apparel, disguised and muffled

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
A goodly city is this Antium. City,
'Tis I that made thy widows: many an heir
Of these fair edifices 'fore my wars
Have I heard groan and drop: then know me not,
Lest that thy wives with spits and boys with stones
In puny battle slay me.
Save you, sir.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: And you.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Direct me, if it be your will,
Where great Aufidius lies: is he in Antium?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p:
He is, and feasts the nobles of the state
At his house this night.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Which is his house, beseech you?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: This, here before you.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Thank you, sir: farewell.

O world, thy slippery turns! Friends now fast sworn,
Whose double bosoms seem to wear one heart,
Whose house, whose bed, whose meal, and exercise,
Are still together, who twin, as 'twere, in love
Unseparable, shall within this hour,
On a dissension of a doit, break out
To bitterest enmity: so, fellest foes,
Whose passions and whose plots have broke their sleep,
To take the one the other, by some chance,
Some trick not worth an egg, shall grow dear friends
And interjoin their issues. So with me:
My birth-place hate I, and my love's upon
This enemy town. I'll enter: if he slay me,
He does fair justice; if he give me way,
I'll do his country service.

p.stage: The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p:
Wine, wine, wine! What service
is here! I think our fellows are asleep.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
Where's Cotus? my master calls
for him. Cotus!

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
A goodly house: the feast smells well; but I
Appear not like a guest.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p:
What would you have, friend? whence are you?
Here's no place for you: pray, go to the door.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
I have deserved no better entertainment,
In being Coriolanus.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
Whence are you, sir? Has the porter his eyes in his
head; that he gives entrance to such companions?
Pray, get you out.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Away!

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p: Away! get you away.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Now thou'rt troublesome.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p: Are you so brave? I'll have you talked with anon.

p.stage: Enter a third Servingman. The first meets him

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p: What fellow's this?

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p:
A strange one as ever I looked on: I cannot get him
out of the house: prithee, call my master to him.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
What have you to do here, fellow? Pray you, avoid
the house.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Let me but stand; I will not hurt your hearth.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: A gentleman.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p: A marvellous poor one.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: True, so I am.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
Pray you, poor gentleman, take up some other
station; here's no place for you; pray you, avoid: come.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
What, you will not? Prithee, tell my master what a
strange guest he has here.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p: And I shall.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p: Where dwellest thou?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Under the canopy.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p: Under the canopy!

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p: Where's that?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: I' the city of kites and crows.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
I' the city of kites and crows! What an ass it is!
Then thou dwellest with daws too?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: No, I serve not thy master.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p: How, sir! do you meddle with my master?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Ay; 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy
mistress. Thou pratest, and pratest; serve with thy
trencher, hence!

p.stage: Beats him away. Exit third Servingman
Enter AUFIDIUS with the second Servingman

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p: Where is this fellow?

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
Here, sir: I'ld have beaten him like a dog, but for
disturbing the lords within.

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p:
Whence comest thou? what wouldst thou? thy name?
Why speak'st not? speak, man: what's thy name?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: If, Tullus,

Not yet thou knowest me, and, seeing me, dost not
Think me for the man I am, necessity
Commands me name myself.

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears,
And harsh in sound to thine.

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p:
Say, what's thy name?
Thou hast a grim appearance, and thy face
Bears a command in't; though thy tackle's torn.
Thou show'st a noble vessel: what's thy name?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Prepare thy brow to frown: know'st
thou me yet?

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p: I know thee not: thy name?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
My name is Caius Marcius, who hath done
To thee particularly and to all the Volsces
Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may
My surname, Coriolanus: the painful service,
The extreme dangers and the drops of blood
Shed for my thankless country are requited
But with that surname; a good memory,
And witness of the malice and displeasure
Which thou shouldst bear me: only that name remains;
The cruelty and envy of the people,
Permitted by our dastard nobles, who
Have all forsook me, hath devour'd the rest;
And suffer'd me by the voice of slaves to be
Whoop'd out of Rome. Now this extremity
Hath brought me to thy hearth; not out of hope—
Mistake me not—to save my life, for if
I had fear'd death, of all the men i' the world
I would have 'voided thee, but in mere spite,
To be full quit of those my banishers,
Stand I before thee here. Then if thou hast
A heart of wreak in thee, that wilt revenge
Thine own particular wrongs and stop those maims
Of shame seen through thy country, speed
thee straight,
And make my misery serve thy turn: so use it
That my revengeful services may prove
As benefits to thee, for I will fight
Against my canker'd country with the spleen
Of all the under fiends. But if so be
Thou darest not this and that to prove more fortunes
Thou'rt tired, then, in a word, I also am
Longer to live most weary, and present
My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice;
Which not to cut would show thee but a fool,
Since I have ever follow'd thee with hate,
Drawn tuns of blood out of thy country's breast,
And cannot live but to thy shame, unless
It be to do thee service.

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p:
O Marcius, Marcius!
Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart
A root of ancient envy. If Jupiter
Should from yond cloud speak divine things,
And say 'Tis true,' I'ld not believe them more
Than thee, all noble Marcius. Let me twine
Mine arms about that body, where against
My grained ash an hundred times hath broke
And scarr'd the moon with splinters: here I clip
The anvil of my sword, and do contest
As hotly and as nobly with thy love
As ever in ambitious strength I did
Contend against thy valour. Know thou first,
I loved the maid I married; never man
Sigh'd truer breath; but that I see thee here,
Thou noble thing! more dances my rapt heart
Than when I first my wedded mistress saw
Bestride my threshold. Why, thou Mars! I tell thee,
We have a power on foot; and I had purpose
Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn,
Or lose mine arm fort: thou hast beat me out
Twelve several times, and I have nightly since
Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me;
We have been down together in my sleep,
Unbuckling helms, fisting each other's throat,
And waked half dead with nothing. Worthy Marcius,
Had we no quarrel else to Rome, but that
Thou art thence banish'd, we would muster all
From twelve to seventy, and pouring war
Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome,
Like a bold flood o'er-bear. O, come, go in,
And take our friendly senators by the hands;
Who now are here, taking their leaves of me,
Who am prepared against your territories,
Though not for Rome itself.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: You bless me, gods!

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p:
Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have
The leading of thine own revenges, take
The one half of my commission; and set down—
As best thou art experienced, since thou know'st
Thy country's strength and weakness,—thine own ways;
Whether to knock against the gates of Rome,
Or rudely visit them in parts remote,
To fright them, ere destroy. But come in:
Let me commend thee first to those that shall
Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes!
And more a friend than e'er an enemy;
Yet, Marcius, that was much. Your hand: most welcome!

p.stage: Exeunt CORIOLANUS and AUFIDIUS. The two Servingmen come forward

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p: Here's a strange alteration!

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with
a cudgel; and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a
false report of him.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p:
What an arm he has! he turned me about with his
finger and his thumb, as one would set up a top.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
Nay, I knew by his face that there was something in
him: he had, sir, a kind of face, methought,—I
cannot tell how to term it.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p:
He had so; looking as it were—would I were hanged,
but I thought there was more in him than I could think.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
So did I, I'll be sworn: he is simply the rarest
man i' the world.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p: I think he is: but a greater soldier than he you wot on.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p: Who, my master?

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p: Nay, it's no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p: Worth six on him.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p:
Nay, not so neither: but I take him to be the
greater soldier.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that:
for the defence of a town, our general is excellent.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p: Ay, and for an assault too.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p: O slaves, I can tell you news,— news, you rascals!

sp.speaker: First Servingman, Second Servingman
sp.p: What, what, what? let's partake.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
I would not be a Roman, of all nations; I had as
lieve be a condemned man.

sp.speaker: First Servingman, Second Servingman
sp.p: Wherefore? wherefore?

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
Why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general,
Caius Marcius.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p: Why do you say 'thwack our general '?

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
I do not say 'thwack our general;' but he was always
good enough for him.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
Come, we are fellows and friends: he was ever too
hard for him; I have heard him say so himself.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p:
He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth
on't: before Corioli he scotched him and notched
him like a carbon ado.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
An he had been cannibally given, he might have
broiled and eaten him too.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p: But, more of thy news?

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
Why, he is so made on here within, as if he were son
and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' the table; no
question asked him by any of the senators, but they
stand bald before him: our general himself makes a
mistress of him: sanctifies himself with's hand and
turns up the white o' the eye to his discourse. But
the bottom of the news is that our general is cut i'
the middle and but one half of what he was
yesterday; for the other has half, by the entreaty
and grant of the whole table. He'll go, he says,
and sowl the porter of Rome gates by the ears: he
will mow all down before him, and leave his passage polled.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p: And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
Do't! he will do't; for, look you, sir, he has as
many friends as enemies; which friends, sir, as it
were, durst not, look you, sir, show themselves, as
we term it, his friends whilst he's in directitude.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p: Directitude! what's that?

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again,
and the man in blood, they will out of their
burrows, like conies after rain, and revel all with
him.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p: But when goes this forward?

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
To-morrow; to-day; presently; you shall have the
drum struck up this afternoon: 'tis, as it were, a
parcel of their feast, and to be executed ere they
wipe their lips.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
Why, then we shall have a stirring world again.
This peace is nothing, but to rust iron, increase
tailors, and breed ballad-makers.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p:
Let me have war, say I; it exceeds peace as far as
day does night; it's spritely, waking, audible, and
full of vent. Peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy;
mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible; a getter of more
bastard children than war's a destroyer of men.

sp.speaker: Second Servingman
sp.p:
'Tis so: and as war, in some sort, may be said to
be a ravisher, so it cannot be denied but peace is a
great maker of cuckolds.

sp.speaker: First Servingman
sp.p: Ay, and it makes men hate one another.

sp.speaker: Third Servingman
sp.p:
Reason; because they then less need one another.
The wars for my money. I hope to see Romans as cheap
as Volscians. They are rising, they are rising.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: In, in, in, in!

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
We hear not of him, neither need we fear him;
His remedies are tame i' the present peace
And quietness of the people, which before
Were in wild hurry. Here do we make his friends
Blush that the world goes well, who rather had,
Though they themselves did suffer by't, behold
Dissentious numbers pestering streets than see
Our tradesmen with in their shops and going
About their functions friendly.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: We stood to't in good time.
Is this Menenius?

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: 'Tis he,'tis he: O, he is grown most kind of late.

sp.speaker: Both Tribunes
sp.p: Hail sir!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Hail to you both!

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Your Coriolanus
Is not much miss'd, but with his friends:
The commonwealth doth stand, and so would do,
Were he more angry at it.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
All's well; and might have been much better, if
He could have temporized.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Where is he, hear you?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Nay, I hear nothing: his mother and his wife
Hear nothing from him.

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: The gods preserve you both!

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: God-den, our neighbours.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: God-den to you all, god-den to you all.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p:
Ourselves, our wives, and children, on our knees,
Are bound to pray for you both.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Live, and thrive!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Farewell, kind neighbours: we wish'd Coriolanus
Had loved you as we did.

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: Now the gods keep you!

sp.speaker: Both Tribunes
sp.p: Farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
This is a happier and more comely time
Than when these fellows ran about the streets,
Crying confusion.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Caius Marcius was
A worthy officer i' the war; but insolent,
O'ercome with pride, ambitious past all thinking,
Self-loving,—

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
And affecting one sole throne,
Without assistance.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: I think not so.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
We should by this, to all our lamentation,
If he had gone forth consul, found it so.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
The gods have well prevented it, and Rome
Sits safe and still without him.

sp.speaker: AEdile
sp.p:
Worthy tribunes,
There is a slave, whom we have put in prison,
Reports, the Volsces with two several powers
Are enter'd in the Roman territories,
And with the deepest malice of the war
Destroy what lies before 'em.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
'Tis Aufidius,
Who, hearing of our Marcius' banishment,
Thrusts forth his horns again into the world;
Which were inshell'd when Marcius stood for Rome,
And durst not once peep out.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Come, what talk you
Of Marcius?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Go see this rumourer whipp'd. It cannot be
The Volsces dare break with us.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Cannot be!
We have record that very well it can,
And three examples of the like have been
Within my age. But reason with the fellow,
Before you punish him, where he heard this,
Lest you shall chance to whip your information
And beat the messenger who bids beware
Of what is to be dreaded.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Tell not me:
I know this cannot be.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: Not possible.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
The nobles in great earnestness are going
All to the senate-house: some news is come
That turns their countenances.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
Messenger
sp.p:
Yes, worthy sir,
The slave's report is seconded; and more,
More fearful, is deliver'd.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: What more fearful?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
It is spoke freely out of many mouths—
How probable I do not know—that Marcius,
Join'd with Aufidius, leads a power 'gainst Rome,
And vows revenge as spacious as between
The young'st and oldest thing.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: This is most likely!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Raised only, that the weaker sort may wish
Good Marcius home again.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: The very trick on't.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
This is unlikely:
He and Aufidius can no more atone
Than violentest contrariety.

sp.speaker: Second Messenger
sp.p:
You are sent for to the senate:
A fearful army, led by Caius Marcius
Associated with Aufidius, rages
Upon our territories; and have already
O'erborne their way, consumed with fire, and took
What lay before them.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: O, you have made good work!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: What news? what news?

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
You have holp to ravish your own daughters and
To melt the city leads upon your pates,
To see your wives dishonour'd to your noses,—

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: What's the news? what's the news?

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
Your temples burned in their cement, and
Your franchises, whereon you stood, confined
Into an auger's bore.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Pray now, your news?
You have made fair work, I fear me.—Pray, your news?—
If Marcius should be join'd with Volscians,—

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
If!
He is their god: he leads them like a thing
Made by some other deity than nature,
That shapes man better; and they follow him,
Against us brats, with no less confidence
Than boys pursuing summer butterflies,
Or butchers killing flies.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
You have made good work,
You and your apron-men; you that stood so up much
on the voice of occupation and
The breath of garlic-eaters!

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
He will shake
Your Rome about your ears.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
As Hercules
Did shake down mellow fruit.
You have made fair work!

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: But is this true, sir?

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
Ay; and you'll look pale
Before you find it other. All the regions
Do smilingly revolt; and who resist
Are mock'd for valiant ignorance,
And perish constant fools. Who is't can blame him?
Your enemies and his find something in him.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
We are all undone, unless
The noble man have mercy.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
Who shall ask it?
The tribunes cannot do't for shame; the people
Deserve such pity of him as the wolf
Does of the shepherds: for his best friends, if they
Should say 'Be good to Rome,' they charged him even
As those should do that had deserved his hate,
And therein show'd like enemies.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
'Tis true:
If he were putting to my house the brand
That should consume it, I have not the face
To say 'Beseech you, cease.' You have made fair hands,
You and your crafts! you have crafted fair!

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
You have brought
A trembling upon Rome, such as was never
So incapable of help.

sp.speaker: Both Tribunes
sp.p: Say not we brought it.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
How! Was it we? we loved him but, like beasts
And cowardly nobles, gave way unto your clusters,
Who did hoot him out o' the city.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
But I fear
They'll roar him in again. Tullus Aufidius,
The second name of men, obeys his points
As if he were his officer: desperation
Is all the policy, strength and defence,
That Rome can make against them.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Here come the clusters.
And is Aufidius with him? You are they
That made the air unwholesome, when you cast
Your stinking greasy caps in hooting at
Coriolanus' exile. Now he's coming;
And not a hair upon a soldier's head
Which will not prove a whip: as many coxcombs
As you threw caps up will he tumble down,
And pay you for your voices. 'Tis no matter;
if he could burn us all into one coal,
We have deserved it.

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.p: Faith, we hear fearful news.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p:
For mine own part,
When I said, banish him, I said 'twas pity.

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.p: And so did I.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.p:
And so did I; and, to say the truth, so did very
many of us: that we did, we did for the best; and
though we willingly consented to his banishment, yet
it was against our will.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: Ye re goodly things, you voices!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
You have made
Good work, you and your cry! Shall's to the Capitol?

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: O, ay, what else?

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Go, masters, get you home; be not dismay'd:
These are a side that would be glad to have
This true which they so seem to fear. Go home,
And show no sign of fear.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p:
The gods be good to us! Come, masters, let's home.
I ever said we were i' the wrong when we banished
him.

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.p: So did we all. But, come, let's home.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p: I do not like this news.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Let's to the Capitol. Would half my wealth
Would buy this for a lie!

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Pray, let us go.

p.stage: A camp, at a small distance from Rome.

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p: Do they still fly to the Roman?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p:
I do not know what witchcraft's in him, but
Your soldiers use him as the grace 'fore meat,
Their talk at table, and their thanks at end;
And you are darken'd in this action, sir,
Even by your own.

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p:
I cannot help it now,
Unless, by using means, I lame the foot
Of our design. He bears himself more proudlier,
Even to my person, than I thought he would
When first I did embrace him: yet his nature
In that's no changeling; and I must excuse
What cannot be amended.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p:
Yet I wish, sir,—
I mean for your particular,—you had not
Join'd in commission with him; but either
Had borne the action of yourself, or else
To him had left it solely.

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p:
I understand thee well; and be thou sure,
when he shall come to his account, he knows not
What I can urge against him. Although it seems,
And so he thinks, and is no less apparent
To the vulgar eye, that he bears all things fairly.
And shows good husbandry for the Volscian state,
Fights dragon-like, and does achieve as soon
As draw his sword; yet he hath left undone
That which shall break his neck or hazard mine,
Whene'er we come to our account.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you, think you he'll carry Rome?

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p:
All places yield to him ere he sits down;
And the nobility of Rome are his:
The senators and patricians love him too:
The tribunes are no soldiers; and their people
Will be as rash in the repeal, as hasty
To expel him thence. I think he'll be to Rome
As is the osprey to the fish, who takes it
By sovereignty of nature. First he was
A noble servant to them; but he could not
Carry his honours even: whether 'twas pride,
Which out of daily fortune ever taints
The happy man; whether defect of judgment,
To fail in the disposing of those chances
Which he was lord of; or whether nature,
Not to be other than one thing, not moving
From the casque to the cushion, but commanding peace
Even with the same austerity and garb
As he controll'd the war; but one of these—
As he hath spices of them all, not all,
For I dare so far free him—made him fear'd,
So hated, and so banish'd: but he has a merit,
To choke it in the utterance. So our virtues
Lie in the interpretation of the time:
And power, unto itself most commendable,
Hath not a tomb so evident as a chair
To extol what it hath done.
One fire drives out one fire; one nail, one nail;
Rights by rights falter, strengths by strengths do fail.
Come, let's away. When, Caius, Rome is thine,
Thou art poor'st of all; then shortly art thou mine.

p.stage: Enter MENENIUS, COMINIUS, SICINIUS, BRUTUS, and others

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
No, I'll not go: you hear what he hath said
Which was sometime his general; who loved him
In a most dear particular. He call'd me father:
But what o' that? Go, you that banish'd him;
A mile before his tent fall down, and knee
The way into his mercy: nay, if he coy'd
To hear Cominius speak, I'll keep at home.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: He would not seem to know me.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Do you hear?

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
Yet one time he did call me by my name:
I urged our old acquaintance, and the drops
That we have bled together. Coriolanus
He would not answer to: forbad all names;
He was a kind of nothing, titleless,
Till he had forged himself a name o' the fire
Of burning Rome.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Why, so: you have made good work!
A pair of tribunes that have rack'd for Rome,
To make coals cheap,—a noble memory!

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
I minded him how royal 'twas to pardon
When it was less expected: he replied,
It was a bare petition of a state
To one whom they had punish'd.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Very well:
Could he say less?

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
I offer'd to awaken his regard
For's private friends: his answer to me was,
He could not stay to pick them in a pile
Of noisome musty chaff: he said 'twas folly,
For one poor grain or two, to leave unburnt,
And still to nose the offence.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
For one poor grain or two!
I am one of those; his mother, wife, his child,
And this brave fellow too, we are the grains:
You are the musty chaff; and you are smelt
Above the moon: we must be burnt for you.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Nay, pray, be patient: if you refuse your aid
In this so never-needed help, yet do not
Upbraid's with our distress. But, sure, if you
Would be your country's pleader, your good tongue,
More than the instant army we can make,
Might stop our countryman.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: No, I'll not meddle.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Pray you, go to him.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: What should I do?

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
Only make trial what your love can do
For Rome, towards Marcius.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Well, and say that Marcius
Return me, as Cominius is return'd,
Unheard; what then?
But as a discontented friend, grief-shot
With his unkindness? say't be so?

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p:
Yet your good will
must have that thanks from Rome, after the measure
As you intended well.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
I'll undertake 't:
I think he'll hear me. Yet, to bite his lip
And hum at good Cominius, much unhearts me.
He was not taken well; he had not dined:
The veins unfill'd, our blood is cold, and then
We pout upon the morning, are unapt
To give or to forgive; but when we have stuff'd
These and these conveyances of our blood
With wine and feeding, we have suppler souls
Than in our priest-like fasts: therefore I'll watch him
Till he be dieted to my request,
And then I'll set upon him.

sp.speaker: BRUTUS
sp.p:
You know the very road into his kindness,
And cannot lose your way.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Good faith, I'll prove him,
Speed how it will. I shall ere long have knowledge
Of my success.

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p: He'll never hear him.

sp.speaker: SICINIUS
sp.p: Not?

sp.speaker: COMINIUS
sp.p:
I tell you, he does sit in gold, his eye
Red as 'twould burn Rome; and his injury
The gaoler to his pity. I kneel'd before him;
'Twas very faintly he said 'Rise;' dismiss'd me
Thus, with his speechless hand: what he would do,
He sent in writing after me; what he would not,
Bound with an oath to yield to his conditions:
So that all hope is vain.
Unless his noble mother, and his wife;
Who, as I hear, mean to solicit him
For mercy to his country. Therefore, let's hence,
And with our fair entreaties haste them on.

p.stage: Entrance of the Volscian camp before Rome.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: Stay: whence are you?

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.p: Stand, and go back.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
You guard like men; 'tis well: but, by your leave,
I am an officer of state, and come
To speak with Coriolanus.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: From whence?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: From Rome.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p:
You may not pass, you must return: our general
Will no more hear from thence.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.p:
You'll see your Rome embraced with fire before
You'll speak with Coriolanus.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Good my friends,
If you have heard your general talk of Rome,
And of his friends there, it is lots to blanks,
My name hath touch'd your ears it is Menenius.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p:
Be it so; go back: the virtue of your name
Is not here passable.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
I tell thee, fellow,
The general is my lover: I have been
The book of his good acts, whence men have read
His name unparallel'd, haply amplified;
For I have ever verified my friends,
Of whom he's chief, with all the size that verity
Would without lapsing suffer: nay, sometimes,
Like to a bowl upon a subtle ground,
I have tumbled past the throw; and in his praise
Have almost stamp'd the leasing: therefore, fellow,
I must have leave to pass.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p:
Faith, sir, if you had told as many lies in his
behalf as you have uttered words in your own, you
should not pass here; no, though it were as virtuous
to lie as to live chastely. Therefore, go back.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Prithee, fellow, remember my name is Menenius,
always factionary on the party of your general.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.p:
Howsoever you have been his liar, as you say you
have, I am one that, telling true under him, must
say, you cannot pass. Therefore, go back.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Has he dined, canst thou tell? for I would not
speak with him till after dinner.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: You are a Roman, are you?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: I am, as thy general is.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p:
Then you should hate Rome, as he does. Can you,
when you have pushed out your gates the very
defender of them, and, in a violent popular
ignorance, given your enemy your shield, think to
front his revenges with the easy groans of old
women, the virginal palms of your daughters, or with
the palsied intercession of such a decayed dotant as
you seem to be? Can you think to blow out the
intended fire your city is ready to flame in, with
such weak breath as this? No, you are deceived;
therefore, back to Rome, and prepare for your
execution: you are condemned, our general has sworn
you out of reprieve and pardon.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Sirrah, if thy captain knew I were here, he would
use me with estimation.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.p: Come, my captain knows you not.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: I mean, thy general.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p:
My general cares not for you. Back, I say, go; lest
I let forth your half-pint of blood; back,—that's
the utmost of your having: back.

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: Nay, but, fellow, fellow,—

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
Now, you companion, I'll say an errand for you:
You shall know now that I am in estimation; you shall
perceive that a Jack guardant cannot office me from
my son Coriolanus: guess, but by my entertainment
with him, if thou standest not i' the state of
hanging, or of some death more long in
spectatorship, and crueller in suffering; behold now
presently, and swoon for what's to come upon thee.

The glorious gods sit in hourly synod about thy
particular prosperity, and love thee no worse than
thy old father Menenius does! O my son, my son!
thou art preparing fire for us; look thee, here's
water to quench it. I was hardly moved to come to
thee; but being assured none but myself could move
thee, I have been blown out of your gates with
sighs; and conjure thee to pardon Rome, and thy
petitionary countrymen. The good gods assuage thy
wrath, and turn the dregs of it upon this varlet
here,—this, who, like a block, hath denied my
access to thee.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: Away!

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p: How! away!

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Wife, mother, child, I know not. My affairs
Are servanted to others: though I owe
My revenge properly, my remission lies
In Volscian breasts. That we have been familiar,
Ingrate forgetfulness shall poison, rather
Than pity note how much. Therefore, be gone.
Mine ears against your suits are stronger than
Your gates against my force. Yet, for I loved thee,
Take this along; I writ it for thy sake

And would have rent it. Another word, Menenius,
I will not hear thee speak. This man, Aufidius,
Was my beloved in Rome: yet thou behold'st!

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p: You keep a constant temper.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: Now, sir, is your name Menenius?

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.p:
'Tis a spell, you see, of much power: you know the
way home again.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p:
Do you hear how we are shent for keeping your
greatness back?

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.p: What cause, do you think, I have to swoon?

sp.speaker: MENENIUS
sp.p:
I neither care for the world nor your general: for
such things as you, I can scarce think there's any,
ye're so slight. He that hath a will to die by
himself fears it not from another: let your general
do his worst. For you, be that you are, long; and
your misery increase with your age! I say to you,
as I was said to, Away!

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.p: A noble fellow, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.p:
The worthy fellow is our general: he's the rock, the
oak not to be wind-shaken.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
We will before the walls of Rome tomorrow
Set down our host. My partner in this action,
You must report to the Volscian lords, how plainly
I have borne this business.

sp.speaker: AUFIDIUS
sp.p:
Only their ends
You have respected; stopp'd your ears against
The general suit of Rome; never admitted
A private whisper, no, not with such friends
That thought them sure of you.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
This last old man,
Whom with a crack'd heart I have sent to Rome,
Loved me above the measure of a father;
Nay, godded me, indeed. Their latest refuge
Was to send him; for whose old love I have,
Though I show'd sourly to him, once more offer'd
The first conditions, which they did refuse
And cannot now accept; to grace him only
That thought he could do more, a very little
I have yielded to: fresh embassies and suits,
Nor from the state nor private friends, hereafter
Will I lend ear to. Ha! what shout is this?

Shall I be tempted to infringe my vow
In the same time 'tis made? I will not.

p.stage: Enter in mourning habits, VIRGILIA, VOLUMNIA, leading young MARCIUS, VALERIA, and Attendants

sp.p:
My wife comes foremost; then the honour'd mould
Wherein this trunk was framed, and in her hand
The grandchild to her blood. But, out, affection!
All bond and privilege of nature, break!
Let it be virtuous to be obstinate.
What is that curt'sy worth? or those doves' eyes,
Which can make gods forsworn? I melt, and am not
Of stronger earth than others. My mother bows;
As if Olympus to a molehill should
In supplication nod: and my young boy
Hath an aspect of intercession, which
Great nature cries 'Deny not.' let the Volsces
Plough Rome and harrow Italy: I'll never
Be such a gosling to obey instinct, but stand,
As if a man were author of himself
And knew no other kin.

sp.speaker: VIRGILIA
sp.p: My lord and husband!

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: These eyes are not the same I wore in Rome.

sp.speaker: VIRGILIA
sp.p:
The sorrow that delivers us thus changed
Makes you think so.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Like a dull actor now,
I have forgot my part, and I am out,
Even to a full disgrace. Best of my flesh,
Forgive my tyranny; but do not say
For that 'Forgive our Romans.' O, a kiss
Long as my exile, sweet as my revenge!
Now, by the jealous queen of heaven, that kiss
I carried from thee, dear; and my true lip
Hath virgin'd it e'er since. You gods! I prate,
And the most noble mother of the world
Leave unsaluted: sink, my knee, i' the earth;

Of thy deep duty more impression show
Than that of common sons.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
O, stand up blest!
Whilst, with no softer cushion than the flint,
I kneel before thee; and unproperly
Show duty, as mistaken all this while
Between the child and parent.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
What is this?
Your knees to me? to your corrected son?
Then let the pebbles on the hungry beach
Fillip the stars; then let the mutinous winds
Strike the proud cedars 'gainst the fiery sun;
Murdering impossibility, to make
What cannot be, slight work.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Thou art my warrior;
I holp to frame thee. Do you know this lady?

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
The noble sister of Publicola,
The moon of Rome, chaste as the icicle
That's curdied by the frost from purest snow
And hangs on Dian's temple: dear Valeria!

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
This is a poor epitome of yours,
Which by the interpretation of full time
May show like all yourself.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
The god of soldiers,
With the consent of supreme Jove, inform
Thy thoughts with nobleness; that thou mayst prove
To shame unvulnerable, and stick i' the wars
Like a great sea-mark, standing every flaw,
And saving those that eye thee!

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p: Your knee, sirrah.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p: That's my brave boy!

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Even he, your wife, this lady, and myself,
Are suitors to you.

sp.speaker: CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
I beseech you, peace:
Or, if you'ld ask, remember this before:
The thing I have forsworn to grant may never
Be held by you denials. Do not bid me
Dismiss my soldiers, or capitulate
Again with Rome's mechanics: tell me not
Wherein I seem unnatural: desire not
To ally my rages and revenges with
Your colder reasons.

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
CORIOLANUS
sp.p:
Aufidius, and you Volsces, mark; for we'll
Hear nought from Rome in private. Your request?

sp.speaker: VOLUMNIA
sp.p:
Should we be silent and not speak, our raiment
And state of bodies would bewray what life
We have led since thy exile. Think with thyself
How more unfortunate than all living women
Are we come hither: since that thy sight,
which should
Make our eyes flow with joy, hearts dance
with comforts,
Constrains them weep and shake with fear and sorrow;
Making the mother, wife and child to see
The son, the husband and the father tearing
His country's bowels out. And to poor we
Thine enmity's most capital: thou barr'st us
Our prayers to the gods, which is a comfort
That all but we enjoy; for how can we,
Alas, how can we for our country pray.
Whereto we are bound, together with thy victory,
Whereto we are bound? alack, or we must lose
The country, our dear nurse, or else thy person,
Our comfort in the country. We must find
An evident calamity, though we had
Our wish, which side should win: for either thou
Must, as a foreign recreant, be led
